questions.text: Mutism and akinesis in a person who is aware of his surroundings and somewhat alert is best described as a feature of: (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stupor

 

The described features of mutism and akinesis in someone who remains conscious of their surroundings but may appear unresponsive are indicative of a stuporous state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state and Option B. Twilight state: It is a dream-like state, in which awareness is restricted, and the patient may feel as if they were in a dream.

 

Option D. Delirium: It is characterized by acute disturbances in attention and consciousness that may be reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference: Sim’s Symptoms in the Mind, 7th edition, Page No 37, 39, 40, 41.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with complaints of confusion and ataxia. Upon examination, nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy were observed. What is the likely diagnosis?  (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wernicke's Encephalopathy

 

The presentation of a 40-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol use, who is experiencing confusion, ataxia, nystagmus, and sixth nerve palsy, is highly suggestive of Wernicke's Encephalopathy. This is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the classic triad of confusion, oculomotor dysfunction (such as nystagmus and cranial nerve palsies), and ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Korsakoff Syndrome: This is a chronic neuropsychiatric syndrome that often follows Wernicke's Encephalopathy. It is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and behavioral changes but lacks the acute neurological symptoms such as nystagmus and ataxia seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Delirium Tremens: This is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by delirium, tremors, agitation, hallucinations, and autonomic instability. While confusion is common, the specific neurological findings of nystagmus and sixth nerve palsy are more indicative of Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. De Clerambault Syndrome: Also known as erotomania, this is a delusional disorder characterized by the belief that another person is in love with the individual. It is unrelated to the symptoms presented in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke’s encephalopathy is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, which is common in individuals with chronic alcohol use due to poor nutritional intake and absorption. Treatment include high dose of parenteral thiamine. Ophthalmoplegia responds first to the treatment, ataxia doesnt improve completely in almost 50% of cases.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: A patient believes he is the most important person in the world, his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him out of jealousy. His wife claims contrary, claiming that he has only recently begun acting in this manner, and that he previously worked calmly as a school teacher. He's probably suffering from? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delusion of grandiosity and persecution

 

The patient's belief that he is the most important person in the world indicates a delusion of grandiosity. His belief that his neighbors and family members are attempting to hurt him due to jealousy represents a delusion of persecution. Both types of delusions are present in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Delusion of grandiosity: Delusion of grandiosity is evident, but this choice doesn't encompass the persecutory beliefs he holds.

 

Option B. Delusion of persecution: While the patient does display delusions of persecution, this choice neglects the grandiose delusion.

 

Option D. Delusion of grandiosity, persecution and reference: The patient clearly exhibits delusions of grandiosity and persecution, but there's no evidence in the provided information suggesting a delusion of reference.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Delusional disorders are characterized by the presence of one or more delusions that persist for at least one month.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 245-246.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

choices.text: Safety - Physiological needs - Self-actualization - Belonging - Self-esteem
Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self-actualization
Safety - Self-actualization - Belonging - Physiological needs - Self-esteem
Self-actualization - Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem

questions.text: Which of the following correctly represents the sequence in Maslow’s hierarchy of needs? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem - Self-actualization

 

Explanation:


Maslow’s hierarchy of needs is a psychological theory proposed by Abraham Maslow, which organizes human needs into a hierarchical structure. The sequence begins with the most basic physiological needs, such as food and water. Once these are satisfied, individuals seek safety and security. Following that, the need for love and belonging becomes prominent, followed by the need for self-esteem. Finally, self-actualization, which is the realization of one’s full potential, is the highest level in the hierarchy.

 

Other options:


Option A. Safety - Physiological needs - Self-actualization - Belonging - Self-esteem: This sequence incorrectly places safety before physiological needs and misorders the remaining needs.
 

Option C. Safety - Self-actualization - Belonging - Physiological needs - Self-esteem: This option incorrectly sequences the needs, placing safety and self-actualization before physiological needs.
 

Option D. Self-actualization - Physiological needs - Safety - Belonging - Self-esteem: This option incorrectly begins with self-actualization and mis orders the other needs.

 

Educational Objective:


Maslow’s hierarchy of needs follows the sequence: Physiological needs, Safety, Belonging, Self-esteem, and Self-actualization, with each level needing to be partially fulfilled

questions.text:
What is utilized to establish dependence among the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)

  1. Strong desire to use the drug
  2. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
  3. Increased tolerance
  4. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

questions.text: Abrupt stoppage of which of the following drugs causes agitation, anxiety and insomnia? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Venlafaxine

 

Abrupt discontinuation or dose reduction of venlafaxine has been known to result in a discontinuation syndrome characterized by agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. This is particularly noted with venlafaxine because of its short half-life. While all the drugs listed can have withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly, venlafaxine is particularly associated with these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Abrupt discontinuation can lead to seizure recurrence in those using it as an antiepileptic and can cause relapse of mood symptoms in those using it as mood stabilizer.

 

Option B. Olanzapine: Stopping it can result in a return of psychotic symptoms.

 

Option C. Imipramine: It can cause withdrawal symptoms, but they are typically more varied and might include headache, nausea, and malaise.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The key features of antidepressant discontinuation syndrome, often abbreviated as FINISH:

 

  • Flu-like symptoms
  • Insomnia
  • Nausea
  • Imbalance
  • Sensory disturbances (e.g., electric shock sensations)
  • Hyperarousal (e.g., anxiety, agitation).

 

It is particularly common with SSRIs and SNRIs with shorter half-lives, such as venlafaxine (most common). Short acting SSRIs such as paroxetine and fluvoxamine are also commonly associated with discontinuation syndrome. Gradual tapering and patient education are essential to prevent and manage this syndrome.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3150.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about behavior change stages and choose the correct answer :(INICET NOV 2023)

 

  • Statement 1: Contemplation – A person who smokes is thinking of quitting smoking.
  • Statement 2: Precontemplation – A person is considering starting morning walk considering its benefits to health.
  • Statement 3: Maintenance phase – A person quit smoking one year back and has not smoked since then.
  • Statement 4: Action phase – A person with obesity says he can't do anything as it runs in his family.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Statement 1 and 3 are correct

 

The behavior change model, often based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM), outlines various stages individuals go through when changing a behavior as given below.

 

 

Statement 1: Correct. Contemplation involves thinking about quitting a behavior, such as smoking, which fits the scenario described.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The maintenance phase describes someone who has successfully sustained a behavior change, such as quitting smoking, over a long period.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. Precontemplation is the stage where a person is not yet considering a change. In this case, considering starting a morning walk suggests the contemplation stage instead.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. This statement reflects a precontemplation attitude where the person is not considering change, attributed to a belief that obesity is inevitable due to family history, rather than being in the action phase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct definitions of stages of behavior change is crucial in accurately assessing an individual's readiness to modify behaviors , based on the Transtheoretical Model (TTM).

questions.text: A known alcoholic patient is brought to the emergency in a disoriented state. He complains of seeing snakes and insects crawling on his skin. Which of the following should be given to this patient? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lorazepam + thiamine

 

Explanation:

 

The patient is displaying signs of alcohol withdrawal, particularly delirium tremens (DTs) which is characterized by confusion, visual and tactile hallucinations (like seeing snakes and feeling bugs crawling on the skin), tremors, and autonomic hyperactivity.

 

  • Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine and is the treatment of choice for alcohol withdrawal, including DTs.
  • Thiamine is essential to administer before or alongside glucose administration to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy in alcohol-dependent individuals.

  • Haloperidol may be used to control severe agitation or hallucinations but is not a first-line therapy for DTs and could lower the seizure threshold.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 631-632.

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion.
There may be neurological conditions associated.

questions.text: What is the false statement regarding somnambulism? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Person will have full consciousness.

 

Individuals who are sleepwalking typically act without conscious awareness and usually have no memory of the episode upon awakening.

 

Other Options:

 

Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a disorder of arousal from slow-wave sleep.

 

Option A. Disorder of sleep arousal: True. Sleepwalking arises from deep, non-REM (NREM) stage 4 sleep, making it a disorder of arousal.

 

Option C. Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion: True. When sleepwalkers are awakened, they are often disoriented and confused.

 

Option D. There may be neurological conditions associated: True. While many cases of somnambulism have no clear cause, certain neurological conditions can be associated with it.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sleepwalking (somnambulism) is an arousal disorder originating from deep, non-REM stage 4 sleep. Individuals who sleepwalk typically act without conscious awareness and have no memory of the episode upon awakening. The person who is having sleep walking is difficult to awake.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555.

questions.text: A person has been referred to you by the court, and you notice a discrepancy between the history they provide and the examination findings. Which of the following conditions should you be particularly aware of in this situation? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Malingering

 

Explanation:


Malingering involves the deliberate fabrication or exaggeration of symptoms for secondary gain, such as financial compensation, avoiding work or legal consequences, obtaining drugs, or receiving a lighter sentence. When a person is referred by the court and discrepancies between history and examination are observed, malingering should be considered, especially if there is a potential for legal or financial benefit. Malingering is not considered a psychiatric disorder but rather a behavior that can lead to misuse of medical resources.

 

Other options:


Option B. Factitious disorder: This involves the intentional production of symptoms, but the motivation is to assume the sick role, not for external gain.
 

Option C. Somatization syndrome: This is characterized by multiple physical symptoms with no identifiable medical cause, typically not associated with deliberate falsification.
 

Option D. Dissociative fugue: This involves sudden, unexpected travel away from one’s usual environment, with an inability to recall one’s past, and is not associated with deliberate symptom fabrication.

 

Educational Objective:


In situations where there is a discrepancy between history and examination findings, especially in legal contexts, consider malingering, where the individual may be fabricating symptoms for secondary gain.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with schizophrenia was started on risperidone. After taking the medication last night, the patient rushes to OPD today with complaints of upwards rolling of his eyes. What is the management of the condition? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promethazine

 

The patient is experiencing oculogyric crisis, which is an acute dystonic reaction caused by antipsychotic medications. This is an extrapyramidal side effect that involves sustained, involuntary upward deviation of the eyes.

 

This is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties. It's commonly used as the first-line treatment for acute dystonic reactions, including oculogyric crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lorazepam: Useful for generalized dystonia or akathisia but not the first line for acute oculogyric crisis.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Another antipsychotic, it wouldn't directly treat the acute dystonic reaction.

 

Option D. Stop antipsychotic: While it might be necessary to review and adjust the antipsychotic regimen if a patient is having side effects, simply stopping the antipsychotic won't provide immediate relief from an acute dystonic reaction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Acute dystonia, an extrapyramidal side effect, is characterized by spasm of muscles in any part of the body, e.g., oculogyric crisis, torticollis. It is seen in about 10% of patients on antipsychotics. Risk factors include young males, those who are antipsychotic naive and high potency antipsychotics. It usually occurs within hours of starting antipsychotic medication. They can be distressing but are reversible. Anticholinergic agents like promethazine (IM or IV) are first-line treatments for these reactions.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 110-111

choices.text: Reactive mood response to positive stimulus
Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of atypical depression? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responds better to TCAs than MAO-I and SSRI

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased sleep: Individuals might sleep more than usual.

 

Option B. Reactive mood: While the individuals typically have a depressed mood, their mood can temporarily lift in response to positive events.

 

Option C. Heaviness of the body: Often described as "leaden paralysis," especially in the arms and legs.

 

However, the claim that atypical depression responds better to tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs) than to monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) is incorrect. In reality, atypical depression often responds better to SSRIs & MAO-Is than to TCAs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Atypical depression, as its name implies, has features that deviate from classic presentations of depression. It is characterized by reversal of vegetative symptoms (i.e., increased sleep, appetite and weight), presence of mood reactivity, leaden paralysis (subjective feeling heaviness of limbs and difficulty in moving them) and extreme sensitivity to interpersonal rejection. SSRIs & MAO-Is have shown efficacy in treating atypical depression, making them a potential therapeutic option for this subtype.

 

Reference: Shorter Oxford Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 197.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nicotine substitution therapy? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

 

 Acidic beverages can interfere with nicotine gum's absorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preferably given by gastrointestinal route: Incorrect. NRT is not given via the gastrointestinal route. Nicotine in NRT is absorbed either through buccal mucosa or skin.

 

Option B. Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death: Incorrect. Varenicline doesn’t come with this black box warning.

 

Option D. Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges: Incorrect. Choice between gum and lozenges depends on individual preference, not blood levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) is an effective method to assist in smoking cessation. It is used to relieve craving for tobacco by substituting nicotine in tobacco with nicotine in safer forms. Various preparations include nicotine gums, nicotine lozenges, nicotine patch, nicotine spray and nicotine inhaler. Nicotine gum's absorption can be affected by acidic beverages, so it's advised to avoid them shortly before or while using the gum.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 684.

choices.text: More common after life threatening trauma
Seen in seizure and migraine patients
Mean age at onset is 25 years

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding depersonalization disorder? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Seen in seizure and migraine patients

 

This is a controversial question as the interpretation of question can be different but based on the given options, the most appropriate answer will be option B. 


As per CTP 11th Edition – Depersonalization is seen in a variety of neurologic and psychiatric disorders and is common in complex partial seizures

 

Depersonalization disorder (DPD) is characterized by persistent or recurrent feelings of detachment or estrangement from one's own thoughts, emotions, body, or surroundings.

 

DPD can be associated with other medical conditions, including seizure disorders and migraines, as stated in option B.
 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. While it can occur as a reaction to life-threatening trauma, it is not specifically more common after such events. 


As per CTP 11th Edition – Many individuals with depersonalization/derealization disorder do not identify an immediate traumatic antecedent and do not report a clear precipitant to disorder onset. On the other hand, nontraumatic stressors—such as severe interpersonal, financial, or occupational losses—have been associated with the onset or exacerbation of the disorder.
 

Option C. The disorder has a slight male predominance.

 

Option D. The mean age of onset for depersonalization disorder is typically in the mid to late teens, not 25 years.
 

Educational Objective: 

 

Depersonalisation disorder is characterized by feelings of unreality or detachment from oneself or one’s body. The patients feel ‘as if’ they have changed. They can be associated with medical conditions such as migraine, seizure disorder, cerebral tumors and encephalitis.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 110

choices.text: Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia
Loss of long-term memory but intact personality
Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory
Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall

questions.text: Which of the following is true statement about Korsakoff syndrome? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). The most common cause is alcohol misuse, but other conditions that affect nutrition can also lead to Korsakoff syndrome. Its main feature is anterograde amnesia with loss of recent memory i.e., patients with Korsakoff syndrome can't acquire new information or recall recent events, but long-term memories from before the onset of the illness remain intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia: Refers to Wernicke's encephalopathy, which often precedes Korsakoff syndrome and presents with a triad of confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia. If left untreated, Wernicke's can progress to Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option B. Loss of long-term memory but intact personality: While long-term memories may be affected in Korsakoff syndrome, it is not a characteristic feature. Personality changes, apathy, and lack of insight can be seen.

 

Option D. Loss of implicit memory and immediate recall: Korsakoff syndrome predominantly affects explicit memory (conscious recall of facts and events), not implicit memory (unconscious memory like skills).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Korsakoff syndrome is a chronic memory disorder caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is primarily associated with chronic alcohol misuse. It is characterized by anterograde amnesia (difficulty forming new memories) and often retrograde amnesia (loss of past memories). Confabulation is common, where patients fill memory gaps with fabricated information. Treatment involves thiamine replacement and abstaining from alcohol. It often follows or coexists with Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is an acute syndrome requiring immediate thiamine treatment.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 38-40.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed escitalopram. Which of the following adverse effect is the least likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sialorrhea

 

Sialorrhea is not typically associated with SSRIs. They are more likely to cause dry mouth. Sialorrhea is a common side effect of clozapine.

 

Other Options:

 

Escitalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI). Among the options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Nausea is a common side effect of SSRIs.

 

Option B. Vivid dreams: Vivid dreams can occasionally be reported but are not the most common side effect.

 

Option C. Anorgasmia: Anorgasmia or other sexual side effects are also commonly associated with SSRIs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Side effects of SSRIs include:

 

  • Most common: Nausea
  • Most common long-term side effects: Sexual dysfunction including delayed orgasm, poor erection and low libido.
  • CNS side effects- Paradoxical anxiety, sedation, vivid dreams, sweating, seizures, EPSE etc.
  • QTc prolongation
  • Weight gain

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, 10th edition, Page No 3156-3158

questions.text: A male patient who just lost his work felt irritated and depressed for the majority of the time. Thinking about the future troubled him, and he was irritated with his family members. He went out to see movies with his friends on occasion and was able to enjoy himself, but when he returned home, he experienced identical sensations. What's the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adjustment disorder

 

The patient's symptoms – depressive mood, irritability, and worry about the future – began after a clear stressor, which in this case is the loss of his job. While he has some features of depression, the ability to temporarily feel better, such as when seeing movies with friends, makes a major depressive episode less likely.

 

This disorder arises within three months of a particular stressor (e.g., job loss) and resolves within six months after the stressor ends or the individual adapts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized anxiety disorder: Chronic worry is a feature, but there is usually no specific identifiable stressor or precipitant, and the duration of symptoms should be at least 6 months.

 

Option C. Mixed anxiety with depression: This isn’t a specific DSM-5 diagnosis. While the patient has symptoms of both, the clear onset after job loss points more towards adjustment disorder.

 

Option D. Moderate depression: The patient’s ability to still experience pleasure (e.g., enjoying movies) makes a full depressive episode less likely.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional responses to stressful events like financial problems, medical illness, relationship problems or death of a loved one. It manifests with emotional or behavioral symptoms which include depressed mood, anxiety, worry, a feeling of inability to cope and some degree of disturbance in individuals daily functioning. The symptoms typically remit within 6 months if the stressor has ended. Treatment of choice is supportive psychotherapy.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 112.

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

choices.text: Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the psychiatry clinic with complaints of frequent, distressing thoughts that his hands are contaminated, leading him to wash his hands compulsively multiple times a day. He spends hours each day on this behavior, which has started to interfere with his work and daily activities. He feels anxious if he tries to resist the urge to wash his hands. His symptoms have worsened over the past six months, and he wants to know the best approach to manage his condition. What is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP)

 

Explanation:

 

Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is a specific form of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) that is considered the gold-standard treatment for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). ERP involves gradually exposing patients to their obsessional triggers, such as the fear of contamination, while preventing them from engaging in their usual compulsive rituals, such as hand washing. This process helps reduce the anxiety associated with obsessions and decreases the compulsive behavior over time. ERP directly addresses the core symptoms of OCD by teaching patients to tolerate distress without performing compulsions, making it the most effective therapeutic approach for long-term management of OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs): SSRIs, such as fluoxetine and sertraline, are pharmacological treatments that can help reduce OCD symptoms, especially when combined with ERP. However, they are not as effective as ERP alone in managing the compulsive behaviors and intrusive thoughts directly and are generally considered adjuncts rather than first-line therapy on their own.

 

Option C. Psychodynamic therapy: Psychodynamic therapy focuses on exploring underlying unconscious conflicts and past experiences that may contribute to a patient’s condition. It is not evidence-based for OCD and does not directly target the compulsions and obsessions that are characteristic of the disorder, making it less effective than ERP.

 

Option D. Antipsychotic medications: Antipsychotics may be used as adjuncts in treatment-resistant OCD when SSRIs and ERP are insufficient. However, they are not first-line treatments and do not specifically address the mechanisms of compulsive behavior and obsessional thoughts seen in OCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP) is the most effective first-line treatment for Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, targeting the core symptoms by reducing anxiety through gradual exposure to triggers and preventing compulsive responses. This approach helps patients gain control over their compulsions and significantly improves their quality of life

choices.text: Phosphatidyl serine

questions.text: Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dipalmitoyl Phosphatidylcholine

 

Explanation

 

  • Respiratory distress syndrome is due to the deficiency of dipalmitoyl-phosphatidyl-choline (DPPC) /dipalmitoyl lecithin. It is the major pulmonary surfactant (surfactant is a surface-active agent, secreted by type II alveolar epithelial cells) It is a complex mixture of several phospholipids, proteins, and ions.
  • The most important components are the phospholipid dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, surfactant apoproteins, and calcium ions.
  • The surfactant decreases the surface tension in the alveoli 2- to 10-fold, which normally plays a major role in preventing alveolar collapse.
  • However, in a number of conditions, such as in hyaline membrane disease (also called respiratory distress syndrome), which often occurs in newborn premature babies, the quantity of surfactant secreted by the alveoli is so greatly depressed that the surface tension of the alveolar fluid becomes several times normal. This causes a serious tendency for the lungs of these babies to collapse or to become filled with fluid.
  • Clinical relevance - Test to assess fetal lung maturity is L/S ratio –lecithin/sphingomyelin ratio. A ratio of ≥ 2 is considered normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphatidyl serine: Incorrect. While phosphatidyl serine is a component of cell membranes and plays roles in signaling, it is not a major component of pulmonary surfactant and is not specifically linked to respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option C. Phosphatidylethanolamine: Incorrect. Similar to phosphatidyl serine, phosphatidylethanolamine is a component of cell membranes and is involved in cellular processes but does not play a direct role in reducing alveolar surface tension or preventing respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Option D. Phosphatidylinositol: Incorrect. Phosphatidylinositol is involved in cellular signaling pathways and membrane structure but is not a significant component of pulmonary surfactant related to respiratory function or the pathology of respiratory distress syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine (DPPC) is crucial for reducing surface tension in the alveoli, preventing their collapse, and is the primary component deficient in respiratory distress syndrome, particularly in premature infants. This deficiency underscores the importance of surfactant therapy in the management of this condition.

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax​ without affecting KmKm​.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm​ (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax​ (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax​ and KmKm​ proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

choices.text: Reassure and advice regular follow up once in 6 months
Confirm USG findings by ordering CT scan
Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of cyst
Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with history of ovarian carcinoma in the mother achieved menopause with smooth transition. She is on hormone replacement therapy. She developed abdominal pain. On examination, a right adnexal mass was palpable and non-tender. On ultrasound, a 3 X 3 cm smooth cyst in her ovary was noted. What is the next best step? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Do CA-125 levels, if normal advise regular check up

 

Explanation:

 

The next best step in managing a postmenopausal woman with a small (3 x 3 cm) smooth ovarian cyst is to measure CA-125 levels. CA-125 is a tumor marker used to assess the risk of ovarian cancer, especially in postmenopausal women. Given the benign characteristics of the cyst on ultrasound and the small size, the initial step is to evaluate CA-125 levels:

 

  • CA-125 Levels: If the CA-125 levels are normal (less than 35), the patient can be advised to have regular follow-ups.
  • Regular Follow-ups: If CA-125 levels are normal, a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) should be repeated in 6-12 weeks to monitor the cyst. If the cyst persists but remains benign, yearly TVS is recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reassure and advise regular follow-up once in 6 months: While reassurance is part of the management, initial evaluation with CA-125 is necessary to rule out malignancy before deciding on the follow-up schedule.

 

Option B. Confirm USG findings by ordering a CT scan: A CT scan is not the first-line investigation for a simple cyst with benign features. Initial evaluation with CA-125 is more appropriate.

 

Option C. Do an exploratory laparoscopy to visualize the nature of the cyst: This is invasive and not indicated for a small, benign-appearing cyst without other concerning features.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Simple cysts in the post-menopausal age grp:

 

  • ≤ 1cm: Considered normal
  • ≤ 5 cm: Ca125; if normal, repeat in 6-12 weeks
  • > 6 cm: Surgical evaluation

 

Ref: Page no 217, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: In which of the following analyses is monetary benefit quantified? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Cost benefit analysis

 

Cost Benefit Analysis (CBA): CBA is a method used to evaluate the total costs versus the total benefits of a project or decision in monetary terms. It helps determine whether the benefits of a project or decision outweigh the costs, thereby justifying the investment. This type of analysis assigns a monetary value to all outcomes, allowing for a direct comparison between costs and benefits. For example, the National Tuberculosis Elimination Program (NTEP) might report that it saved $12 million in a given year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cost Effective Analysis (CEA): Definition: CEA assesses the relative costs and outcomes (effects) of different courses of action.

 

  • Output: It is measured in non-monetary terms such as health outcomes (e.g., quality-adjusted life years (QALY) saved). For instance, the NTEP might measure its effectiveness by the number of lives saved or the improvement in the quality of life.

 

Option C. Network Analysis: Definition: This is a quantitative method that involves mapping out and analyzing the sequence of activities and events in a project.

 

  • Tools: It includes techniques like Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM).
  • Usage: Network analysis is used to identify the sequence of tasks, the longest path through the project (critical path), and to optimize the project schedule.

 

Option D. Input Output Analysis: Definition: This method examines the relationship between inputs and outputs in an economic system.

 

  • Application: It can include both cost-benefit and cost-effective analyses as it calculates the effects of changing inputs on the outputs. This type of analysis is often used in economics to understand how different sectors of an economy interact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CBA [Cost Benefit Analysis] - Results of a program analyzed in terms of MONETARY benefits, e.g. NTEP (2023-24) saved 12 m US $

 

CEA [Cost Effective Analysis] - Output of a program analyzed in terms of RESULTS eg. NTEP (2023-24) save 1.7 Million people can be determined with help of QALY.

 

INPUT-OUTPUT ANALYSIS - Calculation of effects of changing the inputs (Includes CBA & CEA)

 

NETWORK ANALYSIS – It is a quantitative method. It includes activities & events. PERT is sequence of activities. CPM is the longest path in PERT.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. It occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream causing an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis.

 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections are:

 

  • Food poisoning - caused by enterotoxin
  • Toxic shock syndrome- caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome- caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Caused by the ingestion of preformed enterotoxins in contaminated food.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Caused by the release of TSST-1 and other superantigens leading to severe systemic symptoms.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: Caused by exfoliative toxins leading to the destruction of the skin's epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Staphylococcal septicemia is not mediated by toxins, unlike staphylococcal food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which are all toxin-mediated infections.

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne’s negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz. What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 30-45 dB

 

The given clinical scenario of hearing loss with a negative Rinne at 256 Hz and 512 Hz and positive Rinne at 1024 Hz indicates air conduction and bone conduction gap of 30-45 dB.

 

  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz tuning fork (TF) but positive for 512Hz tuning fork → approximate hearing loss will be 20-30dB.
  • Rinne’s negative for 256Hz & 512Hz TF but positive for 1024Hz TF → approximate hearing loss will be 30–45dB
  • Rinne’s negative for all 256Hz, 512Hz & 1024Hz → approximate hearing loss will be 45-60dB.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following blood components with their shelf life:  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

Explanation:

 

The shelf life of blood components varies depending on their storage conditions and preservation methods. Here's a detailed explanation of the correct matches:

 

  1. Single donor platelets: Shelf life is 5 days when stored with continuous agitation to prevent clumping. This is essential to maintain the efficacy and viability of the platelets.
  2. Packed RBC: Shelf life is 42 days when stored in a preservative solution containing saline, adenine, glucose, and mannitol (SAGM). This extends the shelf life while maintaining the quality of the red blood cells.
  3. Cryoprecipitate: Shelf life is 1 year when stored at temperatures below -18°C. Cryoprecipitate is used for patients with clotting factor deficiencies, such as hemophilia A and von Willebrand disease.
  4. Granulocytes concentrate: Shelf life is 24 hours. This component contains white blood cells and is used for patients with severe neutropenia, such as those with febrile neutropenia or aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single donor platelets have a shelf life of 5 days, packed RBCs 42 days, cryoprecipitate 1 year, and granulocytes concentrate 24 hours.

choices.text: Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence

questions.text: A surgeon returns home from a party after many pegs of alcohol and was called to perform an emergency operation. During the operation, the assisting staff noticed the surgeon’s hand shaking and instruments falling. He eventually nicks an artery and the patient collapses. Under which of the following terms will this incident be tried? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Criminal negligence 

 

The incident described in the scenario will be tried under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence refers to a disregard for the safety of others that is so gross or extreme that it constitutes a criminal act.

 

Even in emergency, the surgeon should not have performed operation while under the influence of alcohol.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Civil negligence not amounting to criminal negligence: In this there is no specific and clear violation of law. Simple absence of care and skill. The trial is conducted in a civil court and typically results in fine as punishment. The negligence described in the scenario is too gross to be considered merely civil negligence.

 

Option C. Therapeutic Misadventure (Medical Maloccurence): Individual is injured or died due to some unintentional Act by a doctor/hospital and is not related to the quality of care provided. It is an unforeseen accident due to individual biological variations. Here no one is negligent.

 

Option D. Dichotomy or Fee Splitting or Sharing: Giving of a commission  by  one  doctor  to  another  for  referring, recommending, or procuring any patients for medical, surgical or other treatment. It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by State Medical Council. The punishment can be:

 

  • Warning
  • Penal erasure (professional death sentence).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Performing an operation while under the influence of alcohol and causing harm to a patient constitutes criminal negligence, which is tried in a criminal court and can result in imprisonment and fines.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the emergency department by his family due to sudden, bizarre behavior. He was found wandering outside his home, confused and disoriented. When his wife arrived to see him, he became agitated and insisted that she was not his real wife but an imposter who looks exactly like her. His family reports no history of similar episodes, and he has no history of substance abuse or prior psychiatric illness. A physical exam and routine labs are unremarkable. The patient remains convinced of his belief despite reassurance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Capgras syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Capgras syndrome is a delusional misidentification syndrome in which a patient believes that a familiar person, usually a close family member, has been replaced by an imposter. This condition often occurs in the context of psychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia, dementia, or following brain trauma. The defining feature is the persistent belief in the replacement of loved ones despite clear evidence to the contrary, leading to significant distress and interpersonal conflict. In this case, the patient’s insistence that his wife is an imposter perfectly aligns with Capgras syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder characterized by hallucinations, delusions, disorganized speech, and impaired functioning. While it can include delusional themes, the specific belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter is more characteristic of Capgras syndrome.

 

Option C. Delusional disorder: Delusional disorder involves the presence of non-bizarre delusions without other significant psychotic features. Although it includes persecutory and grandiose themes, it does not typically encompass the specific misidentification of familiar people as imposters seen in Capgras syndrome.

 

Option D. Brief psychotic disorder: Brief psychotic disorder presents with sudden onset of psychosis that lasts less than one month and includes delusions, hallucinations, and disorganized behavior. However, it does not specifically involve the delusional misidentification themes seen in Capgras syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras syndrome is a delusional misidentification disorder characterized by the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an identical imposter. This condition is distinct from other psychotic disorders and requires careful assessment and management to address the specific delusional content and its impact on the patient’s relationships. Understanding the unique features of delusional misidentification syndromes is crucial for accurate diagnosis and effective intervention.

choices.text: Colposcopy with LEEP

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Colposcopy with LEEP

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III (CIN 3) is a severe form of cervical dysplasia that is diagnosed by cervical biopsy. The standard treatment for CIN 2 or CIN 3 is an excisional procedure, which aims to remove the affected tissue to prevent progression to invasive cancer.

 

  • LEEP (Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure):
    • LEEP is the excisional procedure of choice for treating CIN 3.
    • It involves using a thin wire loop that is heated by electric current to excise the transformation zone of the cervix where abnormal cells are located.
    • LEEP is also known as LLETZ (Large Loop Excision of the Transformation Zone).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is a more radical procedure that involves the removal of the uterus. It is generally not the first-line treatment for CIN 3 unless there are other indications, such as concurrent invasive cancer or other gynecological conditions.

 

Option B. Trachelectomy: This procedure involves removing the cervix while preserving the uterus. It is more commonly used for early-stage cervical cancer in women who wish to preserve fertility.

 

Option C. Conization: While conization (removal of a cone-shaped piece of tissue from the cervix) is a valid treatment for CIN 3, LEEP is often preferred due to its effectiveness and lower morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CIN 3 is best treated with an excisional procedure, with the Loop Electrosurgical Excision Procedure (LEEP) being the procedure of choice.

 

Ref: Page no 328, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after sustaining multiple injuries in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and requires a massive blood transfusion. The physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of the transfusion and wants to monitor the patient closely. The physician wants to confirm which of the following adverse effects is not commonly observed in patients who receive a massive blood transfusion? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia

 

This is not a common adverse effect of blood transfusions. Blood transfusions are more likely to cause hypocalcemia due to citrate binding calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypocalcemia: It can occur after a massive blood transfusion because citrate, an anticoagulant used in blood storage bags, can bind to calcium, reducing its levels when the transfused blood is administered. Citrate is used to prevent blood clotting during storage but can have this effect when transfused.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: It can rarely occur after a massive blood transfusion because of dilution of recipient’s blood potassium.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: This is a potential adverse effect of a massive blood transfusion. Stored blood cells can undergo lysis leading to higher potassium levels in the blood products.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypocalcemia and not Hypercalcemia is an adverse effect of massive blood transfusion.
  • Massive blood transfusion instead leads to Hypocalcemia as the anticoagulant citrate binds to calcium.

 

The complications of massive blood transfusion are:

 

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypothermia
  • Alkalosis

choices.text: It has rapid onset of action
It has less depressant action on heart
It has long duration of action
It causes less release of histamine

questions.text: Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It causes less release of histamine

 

Cis-atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent preferred over atracurium for several reasons:

 

  1. Histamine Release: Atracurium is known to cause histamine release, which can lead to hypotension and bronchospasm in susceptible individuals. Cis-atracurium, on the other hand, is a newer and more selective agent that causes less histamine release, making it safer and better tolerated.
  2. Metabolism: Atracurium is metabolized by plasma esterases, which can lead to variability in its effects. Cis-atracurium undergoes Hoffman elimination, a process that occurs at physiological pH and temperature, leading to more predictable and consistent metabolism, independent of organ function.
  3. Cardiovascular Effects: While both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, the reduced histamine release with cis-atracurium minimizes the risk of hypotension and bronchospasm, which can be beneficial in patients with cardiovascular instability.
  4. Duration of Action: Cis-atracurium has a shorter duration of action compared to atracurium, which can be advantageous for titrating doses and facilitating recovery from anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has rapid onset of action: The onset of action for cis-atracurium and atracurium is similar, so this is not the primary reason for preferring cis-atracurium over atracurium.

 

Option B. It has less depressant action on heart: Both drugs have similar cardiovascular effects, and the preference for cis-atracurium is not based on a difference in cardiac depression.

 

Option C. It has long duration of action: Cis-atracurium does not have a significantly longer duration of action compared to atracurium. In fact, its duration of action is similar or slightly shorter, allowing for easier titration and recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cis-atracurium is preferred over atracurium because it causes less histamine release, reducing the risk of side effects such as hypotension and bronchospasm, and it undergoes Hoffman elimination, which contributes to its safer profile and predictable metabolism.

choices.text: Denotes latent CMV infection
Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes
Indicates acute CMV infection
IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

questions.text: Which of the following is true about anti-CMV IgG antibodies? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG avidity assay helps in differentiating past and primary infection

 

IgG avidity assays measure the binding strength between IgG antibodies and virus that can help distinguish a primary CMV infection from a past infection. Following primary CMV infection, IgG antibodies have low binding strength (low avidity) then over 2-4 months mature to high binding strength (high avidity). 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Denotes latent CMV infection: While the presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicates a past infection and potential latent infection, it does not specifically denote the current state of latency.

 

Option B. Denotes chronic CMV infection with immunity to other serotypes: Anti-CMV IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and potential latent infection but do not confer immunity to all serotypes of CMV.

 

Option C. Indicates acute CMV infection: The presence of anti-CMV IgG antibodies alone does not indicate an acute infection; it suggests past exposure. Acute CMV infection is usually indicated by the presence of anti-CMV IgM antibodies or a significant rise in IgG levels over time.

 

Educational objective

 

An IgG avidity assay is a useful tool to differentiate between a primary CMV infection and a past infection. Low avidity IgG indicates a recent infection, whereas high avidity IgG indicates a past infection.

questions.text: The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical parameter used to evaluate maternal health within countries. In the context of public health statistics, how is the Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) for a country conventionally expressed? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Maternal deaths per 100,000 live births

 

  • MMR is Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births.
  • Maternal Mortality ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births, where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a woman while pregnant or during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes’.

 

MMR is a ratio 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is expressed as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births, providing a measure of the safety and quality of maternal care in a country.

questions.text: What does the ECG show? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) P pulmonale

 

The ECG presented shows tall P waves in lead II, which are characteristic of P pulmonale. P pulmonale refers to the presence of abnormally tall P waves in the ECG, usually greater than 2.5 mm in height in lead II. This finding indicates right atrial enlargement, which is commonly associated with pulmonary conditions such as pulmonary hypertension. Right atrial enlargement occurs due to increased pressure or volume overload in the right atrium, often secondary to lung diseases that lead to increased pulmonary artery pressures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: Electrical alternans is characterized by alternating amplitude or direction of the QRS complexes in the ECG. It is often associated with large pericardial effusions and is not indicated by the tall P waves seen in this ECG.

 

Option C. Ventricular bigeminy: Ventricular bigeminy refers to a rhythm where every normal beat is followed by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC). The ECG would show alternating normal QRS complexes with PVCs, which is not seen here.

 

Option D. Improper calibration: Improper calibration of an ECG machine would result in uniformly abnormal waves across all leads, which does not match the specific tall P waves observed in lead II in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

P pulmonale, indicated by tall P waves greater than 2.5 mm in lead II, signifies right atrial enlargement commonly due to pulmonary hypertension or other pulmonary conditions leading to increased right atrial pressure.

choices.text: Presence of a precipitating factor
Acute onset of symptoms
Presence of mood symptoms
Evidence of ventricular enlargement on CT brain

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the psychiatry clinic by his family due to unusual behavior over the past six months. He has become increasingly withdrawn, has difficulty focusing, and sometimes speaks incoherently. His symptoms developed gradually without any clear precipitating event. His family history is significant for schizophrenia in his father. The patient denies any significant mood symptoms, and his CT brain shows evidence of ventricular enlargement. Based on his clinical presentation, which of the following is not considered a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Evidence of ventricular enlargement on CT brain

 

Explanation:

 

According to the prognostic factors for schizophrenia, the presence of ventricular enlargement on CT brain is classified as a poor prognostic factor. Structural brain changes, such as enlarged ventricles, are associated with a more severe disease course, poorer cognitive function, and a less favorable response to treatment. The image provided shows that other poor prognostic indicators include insidious onset, early age of onset, male sex, absence of precipitating factors, hebephrenic or simple subtypes, absence of mood symptoms, negative symptoms, and a family history of schizophrenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a precipitating factor: The presence of a precipitating factor, such as a stressful event, is a good prognostic factor as it suggests the symptoms may be reactive and potentially reversible, aligning with the image’s classification.

 

Option B. Acute onset of symptoms: An acute or abrupt onset of symptoms is associated with a better prognosis, as it often reflects a more favorable response to treatment compared to a gradual, insidious onset, as noted in the provided image.

 

Option C. Presence of mood symptoms: The presence of mood symptoms is classified as a good prognostic factor in schizophrenia because it indicates a more episodic nature of the illness, which generally correlates with better functional outcomes and response to therapy, as shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In schizophrenia, good prognostic factors include acute onset, presence of precipitating factors, mood symptoms, and normal brain imaging. Poor prognostic factors, such as ventricular enlargement on CT brain, suggest a more severe course and worse outcomes. Recognizing these prognostic factors is crucial in guiding treatment and setting realistic expectations for recovery

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Cusco's speculum
﻿﻿﻿Sims' speculum

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cusco's speculum

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is Cusco's speculum.
  • Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualization of the cervix, vaginal fornices and for performing pap smear.
  • Advantage: Self retaining
  • Disadvantage: Less space so can’t be used for some procedures, obscures the vaginal walls so vaginal lesion may be missed

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sim Speculum:

 

 

Option C. Proctoscope

 

 

Option D. Doyen Retractor
