Cusco's speculum is a self-retaining bivalve speculum used for visualizing the cervix and vaginal fornices.

 

Ref: Page no 628, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Gene involved in Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABRA-1

 

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), also known as Janz syndrome, is a common type of generalized epilepsy that typically manifests in adolescents and young adults. It is characterized by myoclonic jerks, generalized tonic-clonic seizures, and absence seizures. A mutation in the GABRA-1 gene, which encodes for the alpha-1 subunit of the GABA(A) receptor, has been linked to juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The GABA(A) receptor is crucial in mediating inhibitory neurotransmission in the brain, and mutations in this gene can disrupt normal neuronal function, leading to the seizures characteristic of JME.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CHYNN-1: This gene is not associated with juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. The correct genes associated with JME include GABRA-1 and others like CLNC2, EFHC1, and CACNB4.

 

Option C. FMR-1: The FMR-1 gene is associated with Fragile X syndrome, which is a leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, not juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because not all the genes listed are involved in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy. Only GABRA-1 from the options given is directly linked to JME.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The GABRA-1 gene is a key genetic factor in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿ETDRS chart - Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study

questions.text: Identify the chart given in the picture below: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hess chart

 

  • Hess chart is a diagnostic tool used to assess the field of a binocular single vision.
  • It is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus.
  • Incomitant strabismus is a type of squint that occurs due to the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies.
  • The chart consists of a smaller chart that indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart that indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.
  • The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: The Snellen chart is used to test visual acuity. Visual acuity is the eye's ability to discriminate between two points.

 

A picture of the Snellen chart is given below.

 

 

Option C: The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background. An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

 

 

Option D: The early treatment diabetic retinopathy study or ETDRS chart presents a series of 5 letters of equal difficulty on each row, with standardized spacing between letters and rows. It consists of a total of 14 lines having 70 letters. It is also used to test visual acuity. An image of the ETDRS chart is given below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hess chart is specifically designed to assess binocular vision and ocular muscle function, especially useful in diagnosing and managing strabismus and similar conditions affecting eye alignment and movement.

choices.text: Muscarinic M2 receptor
Dopamine D2 receptor
Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor

questions.text: G-protein coupled receptor that does not act through opening of potassium channels is(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Angiotensin 1 receptor 

 

G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) can have various mechanisms of action, including the opening of potassium channels or increasing intracellular calcium levels. Opening potassium channels typically results in hyperpolarization and inhibition, whereas increasing calcium levels generally leads to excitation.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor is coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in cardiac tissue where it slows the heart rate.
  • Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor is also coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition. It is involved in regulating neurotransmitter release and motor control.
  • Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts similarly by opening potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition. It plays a role in mood regulation and other central nervous system functions.

 

Angiotensin 1 receptor: Unlike the others, the Angiotensin 1 receptor does not act through the opening of potassium channels. Instead, it is coupled to G-proteins that activate the phospholipase C pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium levels. This results in vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor opens potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in the heart, where it decreases heart rate.

 

Option B. Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor also opens potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition, affecting neurotransmitter release and motor control.

 

Option C. Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts through the opening of potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, influencing mood and other central nervous system activities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GPCR that acts through opening of K+ channels can result in hyper-polarization, thus leading to inhibition. So, receptor which causes stimulation cannot act through opening of K+ channels.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor, Dopamine D2 receptor and serotonin 5HT1 receptor act through opening of K+ channels.
  • Whereas Angiotensin 1 receptor act by increasing Ca2+.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/56

choices.text: Digit Span Forward
Trail Making Test
Clock Drawing Test

questions.text: During a neurological assessment, a 68-year-old woman with no significant past medical history is asked to undergo several cognitive tests due to recent complaints of forgetfulness and difficulty concentrating. The neurologist wants to specifically assess her immediate memory to determine any early signs of cognitive impairment. The patient is asked to repeat a sequence of numbers read aloud to her, and the difficulty increases as the test progresses. What is the name of the test used to assess immediate memory in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Digit Span Forward

 

Explanation:

 

The Digit Span Forward test is a classic test used to assess immediate memory. In this test, the patient is asked to repeat a sequence of numbers, usually starting with shorter sequences that gradually increase in length. This task specifically measures the capacity of immediate memory, requiring the individual to hold and recall information in the correct order for a short duration. The standard span typically tested is up to seven digits, and it serves as a reliable indicator of intact immediate memory functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trail Making Test: The Trail Making Test assesses visual attention and task switching but does not specifically measure immediate memory. It requires the patient to connect a series of numbered and lettered circles in a specific order, primarily testing cognitive flexibility and processing speed.

 

Option C. Clock Drawing Test: The Clock Drawing Test evaluates visuospatial skills, executive functioning, and attention but is not specifically designed to test immediate memory. It involves drawing a clock face with a specific time, testing planning and organizational skills.

 

Option D. Verbal Fluency Test: The Verbal Fluency Test assesses language function, executive functioning, and cognitive flexibility by asking the patient to generate as many words as possible within a category or starting with a specific letter in a short period. It does not specifically assess immediate memory.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Digit Span Forward test is used to assess immediate memory by requiring patients to recall and repeat sequences of numbers in the correct order. This test specifically measures the capacity of short-term memory, distinguishing it from other cognitive assessments that evaluate different aspects of cognitive function. Understanding which tests assess specific cognitive domains is essential for accurate diagnosis and management of cognitive impairments.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell from a motorbike and injured his perineum. He gets an urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood was seen at the tip of the urethra, and swelling of the penis and scrotum was seen. What is the site of injury? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bulbar urethra injury

 

  • Clinical Features: Swelling and bruising in the perineal area; difficulty passing urine; blood at the urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Surgical repair, which may involve primary anastomosis or placement of a suprapubic catheter, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

The presentation of being unable to urinate (urinary retention), the presence of blood at the urethral meatus (hematuria), and the swelling of the penis and scrotum are all indicative of a urethral injury, most likely at the bulbar segment given the described mechanism of injury.

 

The bulbar urethra is the most common site of injury in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma, such as the one described in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Membranous Urethra Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: inability to pass urine; blood at the urethral meatus, suprapubic bulge, floating prostate (Vermooten sign).
  • Treatment Plan: Suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra Injury:

  • Similar to membranous urethral rupture.

 

Option D. Urinary Bladder Rupture:

  • Clinical Features: Severe lower abdominal pain, distention, inability to pass urine, signs of shock (hypotension, rapid pulse). No blood is seen at urethral meatus.
  • Treatment Plan: Immediate surgical repair to close the bladder rupture, followed by drainage of urine, and addressing any associated injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethra injury is a common site of urethral trauma, particularly in cases of straddle injuries or perineal trauma. The key clinical features include difficulty in urination, blood at the urethral meatus, and swelling of the penis and scrotum. The treatment often involves surgical repair or placement of a suprapubic catheter.

choices.text: 2 FC and 1 FAB fragment
1 Variable chain and 1 constant chain
1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

questions.text: When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, which of the following are the end products? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments

 

When papain acts on a molecule of immunoglobulin, the end products are 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments.

 

If an antibody molecule is digested with papain, cleavage occurs above the disulfide bonds that hold the heavy chains together. This generates 3 separate fragments, two of which are called Fab (fragment antigen binding), and one of which is called Fc (fragment crystallizable).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When an immunoglobulin molecule is digested with papain, the end products are 1 Fc fragment and 2 Fab fragments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old chronic smoker came to the medicine outpatient department with complaints of upper chest discomfort and drooping of an eyelid. He also complained of pain radiating to the upper arm and a tingling sensation in the 4th and 5th digits of his left hand. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancoast tumor

 

Pancoast tumors, also known as superior sulcus tumors, are a type of lung cancer located at the apex (top) of the lung. These tumors are particularly associated with several key clinical features and findings, especially in chronic smokers:

 

  1. Upper chest discomfort: This is a common symptom of a Pancoast tumor due to the tumor's location at the apex of the lung.
  2. Drooping of an eyelid (ptosis): This is part of Horner's syndrome, which occurs due to compression of the sympathetic nerves by the tumor. Horner's syndrome typically includes ptosis (drooping eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side of the face.
  3. Pain radiating to the upper arm and tingling sensation: These symptoms suggest involvement of the brachial plexus, a network of nerves that supplies the arm and hand. Pancoast tumors often invade or compress these nerves, leading to referred pain and sensory disturbances in the arm and hand.
  4. Chest X-ray findings: The provided chest X-ray shows a mass at the apex of the lung, which is characteristic of a Pancoast tumor.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper lobe pneumonia: While upper lobe pneumonia can cause chest discomfort and possibly pain, it is not associated with Horner's syndrome or brachial plexus involvement. The X-ray findings would also typically show consolidation rather than a mass.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava obstruction: This condition can cause swelling and discoloration of the face, neck, and upper extremities due to impaired blood flow. However, it does not explain the specific nerve-related symptoms like Horner's syndrome or tingling in the digits.

 

Option D. Aspergilloma: Aspergillomas are fungal balls that develop in pre-existing lung cavities, usually in patients with a history of tuberculosis or other lung diseases. They do not typically present with the neurological symptoms seen in this case, nor do they commonly cause Horner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors, or superior sulcus tumors, are associated with upper chest discomfort, Horner's syndrome, and neurological symptoms in the arm due to their apical location and propensity to invade local structures such as the brachial plexus and sympathetic nerves.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK9 inhibitor? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab
 

Alirocumab and Evolocumab are PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitors. These works by inhibiting the PCSK9 enzyme which is responsible for degradation of LDL receptors in the liver. Therefore, these drugs lead to an increased number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors on liver cells and a subsequent decrease in LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. PCSK9 inhibitors are used for lowering cholesterol levels, particularly in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or those who are at high risk for cardiovascular disease and have not adequately responded to statins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe works by inhibiting the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine, which leads to a reduction in the total amount of cholesterol presented to the liver. It does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Option C. Bempedoic Acid: Bempedoic acid is a relatively new cholesterol-lowering medication. It inhibits ATP citrate lyase, an enzyme involved in cholesterol synthesis, but it is not a PCSK9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Clofibrate: Clofibrate is a fibrate used to lower lipid levels, particularly triglycerides. It works by activating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors (PPARs) and does not inhibit PCSK9.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evolocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that works by blocking the PCSK9 enzyme, leading to increased LDL receptor availability on liver cells and reduced LDL cholesterol levels in the blood.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic and hypertensive patient was carried to the emergency room in a comatose state. On examination, the blood pressure was 170/100 mmHg and pulse rate were >100/min. Plantar reflex was bilateral extensor. What is the next step to do? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Check Blood sugar level

 

Evaluation of Common reversible emergency causes are targeted in the ER. Altered mental status occurring acutely can be remembered with MIST.

 

Step 1. Rx >>> Dx priority (↓ Glucose).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HTN emergency is treated with I.V. antihypertensives.

 

Option C. I.V. mannitol is used in the management of cerebral edema.

 

Option D. CT brain to be done after ruling out life-threatening reversible common causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial management of any comatose patient, particularly those with diabetes, should include rapid assessment of blood glucose levels to rule out hypo- or hyperglycemia as a reversible cause of the coma. This immediate action can be life-saving and should precede other investigations and treatments.

questions.text: In case of meniscal tear, in which of the following zones the healing is best seen? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Red zone

 

VASCULAR REGIONS IN THE MENISCUS

 

  • Vascular supply to the menisci originates predominantly from the inferior and superior lateral and medial geniculate arteries via the perimeniscal capillary plexus.
  • At birth, the entire meniscus is vascular. Following birth, the menisci become increasingly avascular (decrease in vascularity continues up to age 9 years), so by maturity only the peripheral 10-25% of the tissue is perfused.
  • In adults, only 10-25% of lateral meniscus and 10-30% of medial meniscus is vascular.
  • This gives rise to 3 distinct regions of the menisci: 
    • The peripheral relatively vascularized region called the red-red zone (Zone 1)
    • The completely avascular inner 2/3rd zone is known as the white-white zone (Zone 3)
    • Zone of transition between the two (border of avascular and vascular area), which is called the red-white zone (Zone 2)
       
  • There is a direct relationship between the vascularization and capacity of the tissue to heal, predisposing the white-white zone to permanent posttraumatic and degenerative lesions.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Red-white zone. The red-white zone is the middle third with less vascularization but can heal through sometimes.

 

Option C. White zone. The white-white zone has no blood capillaries at all and therefore, cannot heal. They usually require surgery to remove or cut out the torn portion of the meniscus.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The red zone of the meniscus is the most vascularized zone.
  • Any injury at this zone will heal on its own, without a requirement of surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pitting of nails

 

The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

Alopecia areata:

 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaring patches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediated inflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 page no 89.28-33

choices.text: Social anxiety disorder
Autism spectrum disorder

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents because she refuses to speak at school, although she talks normally at home with family members. Her teachers report that she is well-behaved, completes her schoolwork, and interacts nonverbally with her peers but does not speak during class. The parents note that she is shy around strangers but talks freely with close friends and family. There is no history of developmental delays or speech problems, and her hearing is normal. What is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Selective mutism

 

Explanation:

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder characterized by a child's consistent inability to speak in specific social situations where speech is expected, such as at school, despite being able to speak in other settings like home. This condition often arises from an underlying anxiety disorder, such as social anxiety, where the child feels excessively self-conscious or fearful in certain environments. The behavior is not due to a lack of language skills or developmental issues, and the child typically has normal verbal communication abilities in familiar settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Social anxiety disorder: While selective mutism is related to social anxiety, social anxiety disorder itself does not specifically cause selective mutism. Instead, it involves a broader pattern of fear and avoidance of social interactions and performance situations, not limited to speech alone.

 

Option B. Autism spectrum disorder: Autism spectrum disorder often involves significant communication difficulties, but these are usually pervasive across all settings, not limited to specific situations like in selective mutism. Children with autism also have other social and behavioral challenges not seen in selective mutism.

 

Option D. Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD): ADHD is characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity, but it does not typically include selective mutism or significant anxiety around speaking in specific situations. It primarily affects concentration and behavior control rather than selective communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selective mutism is an anxiety disorder in which a child consistently fails to speak in certain settings despite being capable of speaking in others. It is most commonly associated with underlying social anxiety and requires early intervention, including behavioral therapy, to help the child overcome the fear of speaking in specific social situations. Understanding this disorder is crucial in differentiating it from other communication or developmental disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker is expressed on natural killer cell? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CD 94

 

Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of lymphocyte that play a critical role in the innate immune response, particularly in targeting virally infected cells and tumor cells. They are characterized by the expression of specific surface markers, including CD 16, CD 56, and CD 94. CD 94 is particularly important as it forms part of the receptor complex that NK cells use to recognize and interact with target cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD 68: CD 68 is a marker for macrophages and monocytes

 

Option B. CD 3: CD 3 is a pan T-cell marker

 

Option C. CD 25: CD 25 is a marker for IL2

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 356-357

choices.text: Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor.
  • The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection.
  • By inhibiting PDE 5, the hydrolysis if cGMP is prevented, thus leading to erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is another second messenger involved in various biological processes, but it is not the primary mediator in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium plays a critical role in muscle contraction and various cellular functions, but it is not directly involved in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for treating erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate: These molecules are involved in different signaling pathways, such as the phosphatidylinositol pathway, but they are not relevant to the action of sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil, a PDE5 inhibitor, enhances and prolongs erections by preventing the breakdown of cGMP, which is the primary mediator responsible for smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis during arousal.

choices.text: Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation

questions.text: Which of the following does not show both hyperkinetic and hypokinetic movements? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Huntington's chorea

 

Huntington's chorea is characterized by hyperkinetic movements such as chorea but does not typically present with hypokinetic movements.

 

Huntington's chorea presents with a classic triad of abnormal movements (chorea), dementia, and psychiatric manifestations. It also has a strong family history due to its inherited nature.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Parkinson's disease:  Parkinson's disease shows both tremors (hyperkinetic) and bradykinesia (hypokinetic).

 

Option B. Wilson's disease:  Wilson's disease can present with a combination of movement disorders.

 

Option C. Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation:  Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation also shows mixed movement disorders.

 

Educational Objective:


Huntington's chorea primarily presents with hyperkinetic movements and not hypokinetic movements.

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

choices.text: Routine Ha & E

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amyloidosis

 

The given image demonstrates Congo red stain showing Pink red appearance under normal light. This stain is used in diagnosis of Amyloidosis.

 

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Elastic fibers: Elastic fibers can be demonstrated by Verhoeff-van Gieson Stain.

 

 

Option B. Routine H & E: Routine H & E is done by Hematoxylin and eosin stain. The hematoxylin stains cell nuclei a purplish blue, and eosin stains the extracellular matrix and cytoplasm pink.

 

 

Option D. Collagen: Collagen can be demonstrated by Masson trichrome stain. It gives blue color to the collagen, black color to nuclei and red to muscle present.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congo red staining, showing pink-red deposits under normal light, is characteristic of amyloid and is a key diagnostic tool for amyloidosis.

questions.text: Match the malignancies with the responsible genes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Pleomorphic adenoma: This benign salivary gland tumor is associated with the overexpression of the Plag-1 proto-oncogene. Plag-1 plays a significant role in the tumorigenesis of pleomorphic adenoma, making option d the correct match.
  2. Burkitt's lymphoma: This aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma is most commonly associated with the translocation of the C-myc gene, particularly t(8;14) or t(8;22). This translocation leads to the overexpression of the C-myc oncogene, driving the proliferation of lymphoid cells, making option c the correct match.
  3. Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood and is associated with amplification of the N-myc gene. N-myc plays a critical role in the aggressive behavior of neuroblastoma, making option b the correct match.
  4. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma, the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children, is associated with mutations in the Rb gene. The Rb gene is a tumor suppressor that regulates cell cycle progression, and its inactivation leads to uncontrolled cell division, making option a the correct match.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Allergic Interstitial Nephritis
Urinary Tract Infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

questions.text:
A woman presents at 8 weeks of gestation. Which of the following signs can be elicited at this gestation? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Goodell's sign
  2. Osiander's sign
  3. Internal ballottement
  4. Lightening
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Goodell's sign: This sign is the softening of the cervix, which can be elicited around the 6th week of gestation.
  • Osiander's sign: This sign refers to the increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, which can be detected between 6 to 8 weeks of gestation.
  • Internal ballottement: This can be elicited between the 16th and 28th weeks of gestation when the fetus can be felt to move away and return to the fingers upon gentle tap on the cervix.
  • Lightening: This is a sensation of relief of the pressure symptoms due to the engagement of the presenting part, typically felt around 38 weeks of gestation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. 1, 3: Internal ballottement cannot be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation as it is typically felt between 16 and 28 weeks.

 

Option C. 1, 4: Lightening is not experienced until about 38 weeks of gestation, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. 3, 4: Neither internal ballottement nor lightening can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The signs that can be elicited at 8 weeks of gestation are Goodell's sign (softening of the cervix) and Osiander's sign (increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices).

 

  • Signs in early pregnancy are as shown below

 

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74
